title: Mentions of vulnerability and development indices in the UNFCCC national communications
sections:
Mentions of vulnerability and development indices in the UNFCCC national communications

The map shows the mentions of different indices in the UNFCCC national communications documents from 2000 to 2014. National communications are reports that are produced at the national level and then submitted to the UNFCCC by the country in question. They largely contain information regarding the strategies that are being implemented to tackle the challenge posed by climate change at the national level (see also http://unfccc.int/national_reports/items/1408.php). Indices can be climate specific, such as the Global Climate Risk Index or the Global Adaptation Index, or oriented towards more generic issues like the Human Development Index or the Human Poverty Index. It is up to each country to decide when and if they want to submit or renew their national communications and hence the dataset does not contain a document for each country every year. From 1994 to 2014 we analysed a total of 492 documents in which we found 83 mentions of indices beginning in the year 2000.

Figure 1. Mentions of indices over time in the UNFCCC national communications. In the period from 2000-2014 there were 83 mentions of 15 different indices in 492 national communications. Over half of these (49 mentions) were of the Human Development Index (HDI) with the Human Poverty Index (HPI) and the Coastal Vulnerability Index (CVI) being the second most mentioned (6 each).

How to read the map

The map is a stacked bar chart showing the mentions of different indices in different national communications year by year from 2000 to 2014. Each data point represents one or more mentions of one index in one national communications document. This means that if a document cites an index several times it is still counted as one mention. Mentions of each index are stacked together year by year, coloured, and ranked with the most mentioned indices appearing on top. The legend on the right contains information on the total mentions of each index over the entire time period from 2000 to 2014.

How the map is built (map building protocol)

By searching through the UNFCCC’s online Library and Documentation Centre, a total of 492 national communcations were retrieved spanning a quasi twenty-year period from 1994 to 2014 (see http://unfccc.int/essential_background/library/items/3599.php?such=j&symbol=/COM#beg). The number of documents and time range signify the complete amount of national communications that are available to the public through the UNFCCC’s online Library and Documentation Centre, which provides links to PDF versions of the national communications. Scraping the website for the PDF documents was achieved by using the Digital Methods Initiative’s Link Ripper tool (https://wiki.digitalmethods.net/Dmi/ToolLinkRipper) and the DownThemAll Firefox browser plug-in (https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/downthemall/). Specifically, by inputting the URLs of the web pages containing the national communication documents, we captured the links to the PDF versions using the Link Ripper tool and tabulated them in a spreadsheet.17 Due to occasional inconsistencies in the output of the Link Ripper tool, some of the links needed to be retrieved manually and then added to the same spreadsheet. The list of URLs was then saved as a text file that was opened in the Firefox browser, which enabled us to use the DownThemAll plugin to download the PDF versions of the national communications.

The PDFs were retrieved to be queried for the resonance and frequency mentions of 15 different indices. We used the following queries:

Index name

Query

CRED

“vi cred” OR “vi-cred” OR “cred”

CCVI

“Climate Change Vulnerability Index”

EVI

“Environmental Vulnerability Index” OR “El Indice de Vulnerabilidad Ambien”

CVM

“Climate Vulnerability Monitor”

GAIN

“Global Adaptation Index”

SVI

“Social Vulnerability Index”

CRI

“Global Climate Risk Index”

CCPI

“Climate Change Performance Index”

DICE

“DICE econ*” OR “DICE model” OR “DICE économique*” OR“modèle DICE” OR “DICE económico” OR “modelo DICE”

RICE

“RICE econ*” OR “RICE model” OR “RICE économique*” OR“modèle RICE” OR “RICE económico” OR “modelo RICE”

FUND

“Climate Framework for Uncertainty, Negotiation and Distribution”

MERGE

“Model for Evaluating the Regional and Global Effects”

HDI

“Human Development Index” OR “Indice de développement humain”OR “Índice de Desarrollo Humano”

MPI

“Multidimensional Poverty Index” OR “Indice de pauvreté multidimensionnelle” OR “indice de pobreza multidimensional”

HPI

“Human Poverty Index” OR “Indicateur de pauvreté” OR “Índice de pobreza”

GDI

(“Gender-related Development Index” OR “gender related development index” OR “indice de développement selon le genre”OR “Índice de desarrollo humano relativo al género”)

GII

“Gender Inequality Index” OR “Indice d'inégalités de genre” OR“Indice d'inégalité de genre” OR “Indice d'inégalité selon le genre”OR “Índice de desarrollo humano relativo al género” OR “Índice de Desigualdad de Género”

ECVI

“Economic Vulnerability Index” OR “indice de vulnerabilidad economica” OR “indice de vulnérabilité économique” OR “indicateur de vulnérabilité économique”

VASS

“vulnerability assessment” OR “vulnerability index*” OR “vulnerability indic*” OR “vulnerability monitor” OR “indic* de vuln*” OR “évaluation de la vuln*” OR “evaluation de la vuln*” OR “indic* de la vulnerabilidad” OR “evalua* de la vulnerabilidad”

An obstacle that needed to be overcome was the fact that a majority of the national communications were scanned documents in which the text was not searchable. To counteract this problem all the national communications were batch processed for Optical Character Recognition (OCR or ‘text recognition’) in Adobe Acrobat. Once the entire dataset was rendered readable, it was queried in English, French and Spanish. In order to semi-automate the process of searching through the 492 national communications, the querying was carried out using egrep – a command-line utility which enables the researcher to search through lines in plain-text files using a query so as to find matches to that query (which is a pattern) across the text files. The PDFs were therefore first converted into plain text files (we used Poppler, see https://www.macports.org/ports.php?by=library&substr=poppler) and then queried. The results of these grep searches showed which indices were mentioned, by which country and in which year. These results were tabulated in a spreadsheet for further analysis (available here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/16gsqBqssueHcbR5fOWIHW2ykZFU-FfoYy3Bwkb6ct5o/edit#gid=1570746579).
